results.title: LAcrosse; lacrosse
results.brief_description: A slow-motion exploration of the grace and beauty of the women’s game of lacrosse featuring the United States Women’s Lacrosse Association. The women’s game differs significantly in spirit and in rule from the men’s game in that the women have eliminated boundaries and disallowed body contact.

results.title: La Lutte contre le froid
results.creator_credit: Henri Gruel and Son et Lumiere
results.brief_description: An amusing and well made cartoon, light heartedly pouring scorn on our feeble efforts throughout the centuries to keep warm and resist the hardy since it can be used in so many forms and the widest range of heating systems. Blends animation and live action in an incisive and witty manner which can be enjoyed as much for its vigorous invention as for the precision of its technique.

results.title: La Garonne
results.brief_description: One of a series of teaching films with commentary in simple french. Sketches the outlines of france and the course of the river with its tributaries, before presenting its source in the Pyrenees whose peaks we see as we descend close to the torrent through gorges and ravines.

results.title: L.A.: as suggested by the art of Edward Ruscha
results.creator_credit: Gary Conklin and Gary Conklin Films
results.brief_description: Edward Ruscha’s paintings, drawings and photographs are the point of departure for this impressionistic study of Los Angeles’ buildings, apartment houses, palm trees, swimming pools, cars and signs, enhanced by the city’s unique winter light. Features music by Gershwin, Django Reinhardt, Eric Satie, Czerny, M. Lecudna. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Kuumba: Simon's new sound
results.creator_credit: Nguzo Saba, Carol Munday Lawrence and Nguzo Saba Films
results.brief_description: Animated film about a young boy living in Trinidad who experiments with various sounds to create an instrument to play in the Mardi Gras. Shows his success in fabricating a steel drum from the bottom of an oil drum. Written by Joel Dreyfuss, designed and animated by Robert Bloomberg and Jane Aaron, narrated by Lawrence Andrews, Lucille Arnold, Pamela Franco and Opal Palmer. Music by ‘The Louis Arnold Steel Drummers’.

results.title: Kuhle wampe: Oder wem gehort die welt? = To Whom does the world belong?
results.brief_description: This film is a docu-drama focused on working class life in Berlin during the early thirties. Kuhle Wampe was a camp for the unemployed on the outskirts of the city. Anni, stifled by Kuhle Wampe’s inhabitants’ desire for bourgeois respectability finds new purpose in a left-wing youth movement. Brecht, co-author Ottwalt and friend, young Bulgarian director, Dudow, saw the film as contrasting ‘the petty bourgeois world and the politically conscious workers’ sports environment… (to) show how young people grow out of the middle-class confines into proletarian solidarity’, to quote Dudow. The film’s didacticism (characters as representative of their class) is combined with an almost lyrical naturalism. Kuhle Wampe was banned by the Nazis in 1933. In German with English subtitles. Cast includes Hertha Thiele, Ernst Busch, Martha Wolter and Lilli Schonborn. Notes by Hans Gunther Pflaum. The film is followed by a video essay by freelance writer, former film critic and teacher Andrew Hoellering, son of ‘Kuhle Wampe’s‘ producer, Georg Hoellering.

results.title: Krasner, Norman...beloved husband of Irma
results.brief_description: A film without dialogue employing the universal language of comedy to capture the tribulations of a man attempting to use a pay toilet. Written by James Herbert. Cast includes Douglas Macintosh, David Thompson and David Kelly.

results.title: Kontraste (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Produced by an international team of amateur film makers aged 18 to 23, this is an experiment in the synthesis of ballet and film techniques. Elements of both dance-drama and traditional ballet are used in a psychological fantasy set against the ruins of a city, describing the impact of new people and strange feelings on youth. The “Contrasts” are those of white to black, youth to experience, the unreal formality of the ballet as opposed to the rough reality of the setting. Sound effects and music only.
